metadata.title: Building a solubility predictor. Neural networks in the name of science | by Flawnson Tong | Towards Data Science

all_paragraphs: People are sleeping on what is one of the most exciting events of the 21st century; the intersection of technologies and sciences. Like two galaxies colliding, science and technology is continuing to blur the lines between industries, as we begin to realize and reap the benefits of collaboration.

One of the most notable cooperative engagements is the budding new relationship between A.I and Chemistry. What started off as cheminformatics has accelerated the archaic research processes of the past and turned research groups in industry and academia alike towards faster chemical innovation. These new insights have opened new avenues for research and unleashed a very important byproduct: data.

Our understanding of science has led us to see the bigger picture, and it’s now more obvious than ever that there is little that separates physics from biology, electronics from textiles, and any other field. Our research method has shifted from empiricism to a more data driven approach, especially as we begin to understand the underlying patterns in the data we have.

Data is useful to make predictions, run simulations, and use for a whole host of computational processes that speed up the scientific method by several years; and it only gets faster as we gather more data.

While still in short supply, especially compared to the vast datasets of text, numerical, and image data, chemical data is slowly on the rise, and the silver lining is clear; we’re getting closer and closer to a technological convergence. Yuval Noah Harari believes it is this convergence of Data/A.I and Biology/Biotechnology that will define the future of humanity. If biology is indeed the yin to data’s yang, then physics and chemistry is the catalyst for this matrimony. After all:
Biology is just living chemistry, and chemistry is technically just applied physics.
Nevertheless, the direction is clear; A.I and chemistry are a match made in heaven.

Using the SMILES molecular representation format, I built a neural network capable of predicting the solubility of a given molecule. Trained on a data set of over 1000 data points, the predictor is capable of predicting the solubility of molecules with decent accuracy.
The project is divided into 4 parts

Using a similar technique as my molecular charge classifier neural network, I turned the SMILE strings into binary fingerprints of 256 bits each. This allowed the algorithm to input one bit per input neuron (hence the 256 neuron input layer). Since solubility can be negative, I used the tanh activation function, as tanh accounts for negative values.

As the loss function, this project used mean squared error with an Adam optimizer, as both are well suited for single output predictions. With my dataset of 1000 molecules, I trained the algorithm at a learning rate of 0.0005 and a batch size of 5, over 200 epochs. 10% of the 1000 SMILE strings was kept as validation data.

Upon training, I realized that while the loss was indeed decreasing, the accuracy was constantly less than 1%. After much toiling over the potential bugs, I realized the problem wasn’t with the algorithm or with my data preprocessing technique; the problem was the data itself. After some research I learned that solubility is determined by both component and structure. This is very important, since my data format does not indicate 3 dimensional structure, only a molecule’s components.

More important however, are the environmental variables. External conditions like temperature and pressure have impact on a molecules solubility. None of theses conditions where specified in the algorithm, hence the algorithm could not be trained.

Ultimately, the algorithm failed to predict the solubility of the 10 test molecules that where put aside with meaningful accuracy. The same algorithm can be used across other purposes, and so I uploaded the code to Github. The repository includes 2 sets of data and the model file.
